ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained skills in microbiology techniques, such as isolation streaming and gram stain.
You learn about microscopy and staining techniques.
I learned the basics of microbiology lab techniques such as streaking out single colonies, various types of staining, and using a microscope.
Basic microbiology laboratory techniques including various stains, microscopy, and biochemical tests

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course covers many techniques and has mini projects, which is a strength.

The contents and experiments of the course were very fun and engaging and allows for a deeper understanding of the material. However, at times, the course could be kind of unorganized, so there was a bit of confusion on what was going on for that week of class.

The course is definitely good practice for micropipetting, plating bacteria, working with light/phase contrast microscopy, etc. I appreciated how the course reinforced techniques by having us perform most of them multiple times. The lab reports never felt overwhelming but were a good way to consolidate all the information.

In terms of weaknesses, the course organization definitely stood out. Lab handouts typically weren't posted until the morning of the lab, leaving us in the dark about what we'd actually be doing. Due dates were also somewhat poorly communicated, and it was difficult to get in touch with the instructor over email. Additionally, I felt like the last third of the course ("medical microbiology"), while somewhat interesting, was fairly similar to the middle third in that the goal was still to identify bacterial isolates. I think introducing more techniques or setting different goals would've made for a more engaging conclusion to the semester.

The class was extremely poorly organized. Due dates for assignments were changed or announced sometimes days before, or changed even after the initial due date had already passed. Lab protocols were posted at inconsistent hours, sometimes only shortly before the start of class periods, or not at all. No guidelines or rubrics were provided for assignments until well after mid-semester, and it was difficult to contact the teaching team.

This course was well organized for our learning. Professor Wertz was always available to provide his knowledge and help and I learned so much through this course. One thing, however, is that I wish assignment due dates were posted earlier as they were often posted very close to the deadline.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend, because you learn many essential skills.
Yes, I think this is one of the more relaxed lab class in the major, but you still learn a lot and the experiments are not difficult but very fun and engaging.
Sure, it's an easy enough lab that gets you comfortable with some basic techniques. Not super exciting if that's what you're looking for.
Never. The disorganization of the course leads to it being a stressful experience with minimal actual learning.
Definitely! If you've taken microbiology and enjoyed it, you'll like this course. It's not a crazy workload but you learn so much!
If necessary to fulfill MCDB requirement
